qas.question: What is a retified versionof ASCII?
What type of extensions do these other character encodings have?

answers.text: extensions for characters outside the English alphabet and symbols used outside the United States

qas.question: Why did most countries need a adapted version of ASCII?

answers.text: ASCII suited the needs of only the USA and a few other countries

qas.question: Why are the other versions of ASCII not true ASCII?

answers.text: true ASCII is defined strictly only by the ANSI standard

qas.question: What is an identical version of ASCII?

plausible_answers.text: extensions for characters outside the English alphabet and symbols used outside the United States

qas.question: What type of extensions do these other standard bodies have?

plausible_answers.text: ASCII suited the needs of only the USA and a few other countries

qas.question: Why did Brasil need an adapted version of ASCII?

plausible_answers.text: true ASCII is defined strictly only by the ANSI standard

qas.question: Why are the other versions of ASCII charging extra for extensions?
What country had it own version that supported international standards?

context: Other international standards bodies have ratified character encodings such as <a0_0><b4_0>ISO/IEC 646<b4_0/><a0_0/> that are identical or nearly identical to ASCII, with <a1_0><b5_0>extensions for characters outside the English alphabet and symbols used outside the United States<b5_0/><a1_0/>, such as the symbol for the United Kingdom's pound sterling (£). Almost every country needed an adapted version of ASCII, since <a2_0><b6_0>ASCII suited the needs of only the USA and a few other countries<b6_0/><a2_0/>. For example, <b8_0>Canada<b8_0/> had its own version that supported French characters. Other adapted encodings include ISCII (India), VISCII (Vietnam), and YUSCII (Yugoslavia). Although these encodings are sometimes referred to as ASCII, <a3_0><b7_0>true ASCII is defined strictly only by the ANSI standard<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
